qas.question: Different documents that represent the same original text are called what?
What are the variations in the text of witnesses known as?

answers.text: variant readings, or simply variants or readings.

qas.question: How or why do variations enter a witness text?

answers.text: either by accident (duplication or omission) or intention (harmonization or censorship)

qas.question: As well as representing the original text, a critical text must also do what?
Why is it important to document variations in witness texts when compiling a critical text?

answers.text: so the relation of extant witnesses to the reconstructed original is apparent to a reader of the critical edition.

qas.question: Identical documents that represent different text are called what?
What are the similarities in the text of witnesses known as?
When do variations enter a witness text?
What is the fourth way the textual critic considers evidence?
What is the fifth way the textual critic considers evidence?

context: <b7_0>When comparing different documents<b7_0/>, or "<a0_0><b5_0>witnesses<b5_0/><a0_0/>", of a single, original text, the observed differences are called <a1_0>variant readings, or simply variants or readings.<a1_0/> It is not always apparent which single variant represents the author's original work. The process of textual criticism seeks to explain how each variant may have entered the text, <a2_0>either by accident (<b6_0>duplication<b6_0/> or omission) or intention (harmonization or censorship)<a2_0/>, as scribes or supervisors transmitted the original author's text by copying it. The textual critic's task, therefore, is to sort through the variants, eliminating those most likely to be un-original, hence establishing a "critical text", or critical edition, that is intended to best approximate the original. At the same time, the critical text should <a3_0>document variant readings<a3_0/>, <a4_0>so the relation of extant witnesses to the reconstructed original is apparent to a reader of the critical edition.<a4_0/> In establishing the critical text, the textual critic considers both <b8_0>"external" evidence<b8_0/> (the age, provenance, and affiliation of each witness) and "internal" or "<b9_0>physical<b9_0/>" considerations (what the author and scribes, or printers, were likely to have done).
